item.title: Updating Blog, etc.
item.description:
So I have been updating this website and blog. I wrote an About page in ReStructuredText (.rst), which is apparently frequently used in Python documentation. It it is pretty straightforward, though I found the hyperlink format to be a bit of a pain and also rather hard to figure out. I see a lot of possibilities for this sort of format for for my own work, as I am trying to work collaboratively and deal with simple text as much as possible. I may want to make an extension to handle Hindi/Urdu related things. Apparently Markdown, the alternative to RST, is not quite as extendable. But it's easy enough to switch back and forth. The one thing that is a bit of a problem for me is the lack of a spell- or grammar- checker. I normally type in some sort of Office suite, and so I am used to that being there. There is a ":set spell" command in Vim (the editor I am currently using) that can at least find misspelled or strange words. It does not know the words "blog" or "hyperlink," though, so I have some concerns already.

I wanted to try out the iPython Notebook integration features of this blog software, but then was told my iPython was too old. So I updated to 1.1. I had to update my Python package management system as well. It has a new name but is still free for people with .edu addresses. It seems like there are only two major ones–one named after a snake, and one about a place where a snake would be kept. And of course the software is a type of–. I thought it was leading up to a Sun vs. Eclipse thing. Kind of, maybe. But all in the descriptive system of the snake. That last sentence really reminds how much I want to write a blog post about Riffaterre. All in due course...

I found that inserting images, javascript snippets, etc. will not be a problem at all. That's good.

Long story short, I have not yet integrated iPython Notebook, but I will try again. The other thing I want to check is how to best get this blog 1) onto Github and 2) onto my web server. I need to remember to turn off RST indexing for search engines.

I have also seen a few examples of CVs written in RST. It is a perennial pain to update my CV in Word, so I may try and move it into RST and see how it looks. I want to be able to link to it on the top of my page and then to be able to link to subheadings within it, especially projects and articles. I will see how that all works. Apparently it is easy to turn the .rst files into .pdf etc. Then I can just have a general link if people need it. Of course, most places then need a two-page one or an under-five-page one, etc., etc., so maybe it's not such a good idea after all. I will see how difficult it is and then decide whether or not it is worth it. I did recently see a beautifully designed CV by an artist, so I may be able to model mine on that.
